The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

ADVERTISEMENTS.– P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20, every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news columns P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
N.B.– Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1904.

div.head: A BIG BLOW
div.p: a terrific struggle they needed, at 5 o'clock in the evening, in reaching their goal. An official telegram from Tokyo to-day states that the Russians left "heaps of corpse" on the eastern side of the hill, This success is of extreme importance as the port will be at the mercy of the. Japanese guns, and the significance of Wednesday's fear is that it is the beginning of the end.

The importance of Port Arthur to the Russians consists in the fact that it occupies a large portion of the Japanese forces, both naval and military, and thereby assists General Kuropatkin and the commanders of the Russian Squadrons. But if the fortress should fall during the next few weeks, before the Baltic Squadron has passed the Philippine Islands, the whole aspect of the war will be changed to Japan's advantage. After a sufficient garrison has been left for Port Arthur, of which the Japanese would at once restore and re-arm the defences towards the sea, a very large contingent would be available to reinforce Marshal Oyama's Army, while Admiral Togo's whole Fleet, except the vessels with which he observes the Vladivostok Squadron, would be available to fight the Fleet from the Baltic. Admiral Togo has hitherto been necessarily obliged to consider in all his arrangements the possibility that the Baltic Fleet might be sent to Japanese waters. He has, therefore, had to avoid a close action in which the destruction of the enemy's ships might be purchased at the -cost of serious loss to his own squadron, for if such loss were to reduce his force below what is indispensable for a fight with the Baltic Fleet the arrival of that Fleet might turn in Russia's favour the balance of power at sea. The Japanese admiral has so far been able to keep his Fleet almost at full strength; he has lost only one battleship, and few competent judges think that the Baltic Fleet unaided can have much chando against him. But it is still as important to him as ever that Port Arthur should become as soon as possible a Japanese harbour and fortress, and that the men-of-war there should either cease to be Russian or cease to exist. If the Japanese are right in supposing that their bombardment has already damaged some of the vessels the possibilities of another sortie must be much diminished, and the probability is that before surrender or before the last assault the Russians will attempt to destroy those of their men-of-war which still remain. In a fight with the Baltic Fleet Admiral Togo will not need to avoid a close action, for there is no other Russian Fleet available, and the destruction of the Baltic Fleet,even it it cost half of the Japanese Squadron, would leave Japan mistress of the sea until the end of the war. No ships but those of Russia can take part in the conflict without compelling the British Navy to take part on the side of Japan.

div.head: MANCHURIA.
div.p: RUSSIAN REPULSES.
FORTIFIED PASS CAPTURED.
TOKIO, December 1..
Marshal Oyama's despatches only report a few skirmishes in which the Russians have invariably been repulsed.
(Reuter.)

ST. PETERSBURG, December 1. General Kuropatkin on the 30th ult. reports that a rearguard of the Japanese, retreating from Tsin-khe-chou, was driven on the 29th from a pass where they had halted. The Russian losses were slight. The Japanese retired on another fortified pass, situated a mile and a half further away, which we captured to-day after a short but stubborn resistance. (Reuter.)

div.head: GENERAL NEWS.
div.p: FRENCH CHAMBER.
ANOTHER DUEL IN PROSPECT.
PARIS, December 1.
CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES.-M. Sembat re- proached M. Chaumiés, Minister of Public Instruction, with the removal of Prof. Thalamas. The Chamber passed a vote of confidence in the Government.
In consequence of this incident, M. Jaurès sent his seconds to M. Déroulède.

div.head: ITALIAN CHAMBER.
div.p: (Havas.)
ELECTION OF PRESIDENT.
ROME, December 1.
Sig. Marcora has been elected President of
the Chamber of Deputies.
(Havas.)
ROME, December 2.
Signor Marcora has been elected President
of the Chamber.
(Reuter.)

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.-
div.p: The adjourned meeting of the Commission will be held to- morrow at 9 p.m.
The

div.head: THE CAIRO WEEKLY NEWSPAPER,
div.p: Sphinx, will make its first appearance this season on Saturday, 10th inst.

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS
div.p: found in the Mousky and Abdeen quarters of Cairo during the nights of the 4th and 5th inst. will be poisoned by the police.
DRAMATIC PERFORMANCE.
On Saturday next, at 4.30 p.m., the Cercle de la Jeunesse Catholique will give a performance of "Les piastres rouge" in aid of a home for the aged poor at the Choubra Church of the African Mission.
LOTS TURCS.-

The Alexandria agency of the Credit Lyonnais informs us that the winning S number in yesterday's drawing at Constantinople of the Ottoman Railway Lottery bonds e is 487,010, which entitles the fortunate holder to 600,000 francs.
BRITISH RECREATION CLUB.-

Dr. Madden gave the second lecture on "First Aid to the Injured" on Tuesday evening, the subject being "The Organs of Circulation," with illustrations of the places where pressure is to be applied to stop hemorrhage, and the mode of bandaging in such cases.
SHEPHEARD'S.

One of the invariable signs of the approach of the Cairo season is the reopening of the grill-room at Shepheard's. Yesterday saw the reopening of this shrine of the epicure and the grill was well patronised. may mention that the restaurant and grill- room are also open for residents.
We
SUEZ CANAL.

On the 29th ult. 7 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 5 were British, 1 German, and 1 Egyptian. The transit and passenger dues for the day amounted to 159,884.59 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 382 vessels amounted to 9,968,416.91 francs.
ALEXANDRIA POPULAR UNIVERSITY.

Yesterday evening, Commandant Sylvain, the Envoy Extraordinary of the Republic of Haiti to the Emperor Menelik, gave a most interest- ing lecture at the Alexandria University. The subject of his discourse was the necessity for harmonious relations between the white and black races in this continent, which subject he recently dealt with at the Khedivial Geographical Society. The style in which his discourse was given elicited the general admiration of his audience. He was most severe last night in his criticisms of German methods of colonisation in Africa and of the way the Teutons treat their black subjects. Commandant Sylvain is leaving Alexandria shortly for Rome on a mission from the Republic of Haiti to the Pope.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR.
div.p: TAKING OF 203 METRE HILL.
FIERCE JAPANESE CHARGE.&
IMPORTANT ADVANTAGE.
TOKIO, December 1. 8
The Japanese remain masters of 203 metres
hill.
(Havas.) 1
TOKIO, December 1.
The 203 metre hill is on the western side of 1 the harbour, and commands the whole port, thus enabling the Japanese to cannonade the warships.

The Japanese, by means of tunnels and mines, blew up the glacis of the hill. Huge masses fell into the moat, and partially filled ] it. The besiegers commenced the bombardment at dawn yesterday, and made several charges, which, however, were stubbornly resisted. They made another fierce charge at 5 o'clock in the afternoon, and reached within 30 metres of the summit. Being then reinforced, they charged to the top, and occupied the hill at 5 o'clock in the evening. Simultaneously, the forces operating against the north-eastern part charged, and the entire fort was captured. (R.)
TOKIO, December 1.
(Official). The Russians left heaps of corpses on the eastern side of 203 metre hill.
The Japanese Lieutenant-General Tsuchiya was wounded, and Lieutenant-General Naka- mura on the 27th November was injured in both his legs. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive spent yesterday at Koubbeh Palace.

His Highness will receive in audience at Abdeen Palace this afternoon Senor Ricardo Larios, Spanish Diplomatic Agent, Mirza Aly Azhar Khan, who will present to his Highness M. J. Naus, Minister of Customs and Postmaster in Persia, and his son, M. Henri Naus, director of the Sucreries at Nag Hamadi, and M. Nanello, 1st Dragoman of the Persian Diplomatic Agency.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers will meet on Satur- day afternoon at Abdeen Palace under the presidency of the Khedive.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: According to the Sudan Gazette, Kaimakam Palmer Bey, A.A.G. to the Egyptian Army, will replace Miralai Asser Bey, who is to be nominated Secretary-General to the Sudan Administration, as Financial Secretary to the Ministry of War.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: During the week ending yesterday, 20 deaths have been reported as due to bovine typhus in the whole of Egypt, against 13 reported during the previous week, showing an increase of 7. The number of deaths reported during the corresponding week last year, viz., from the 23rd to the 29th November, amounted to 809. Since the beginning of the epidemic the total number of deaths amounts to 146,593, distributed as follows: Gouvernorats, 853; Lower Egypt, 53,610; Upper Egypt, 92,130. During the past week no new localities have been reported infected, while 1,827 animals have been inoculated with serum.

div.head: MAD DOGS.
div.p: A mad pariah dog was seen on Wednesday in Kasr El Dobara. It bit four private dogs
f and two cats. Whilst in a paroxysm, it was killed by Mr. Mason, of the Sanitary Depart- ment, whose dog was amongst the victims.

The police are taking to poisoning dogs in the morning instead of at night, that being a more convenient hour to catch the dogs. These cold nights, dogs do not care to frequent the streets, but come out in the morning in search d of food.

"Love me love my dog" (Cairo) writes:- Pray do not recommend that the adoption of the cruel English system of isolation should be applied to Egypt. I have been a stranger to my native land for ten long years because I would not allow my poor pet to be taken from The day that they introduce those iniquitous regulations of the Board of Trade or Board of Agriculture-I do not remember which I shall leave Egypt, never to return, rather than submit to them:
me.

div.head: ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS, GHIZEH.
div.p: The arrivals in the menagerie from the 20th to the 30th ulto. included one Indian sand-boa,. presented by Dr. Franz Werner, one Kra monkey, from the East Indies, presented by Mr. Howard Carter, and one Moila snake, caught at Abou-Roash, and purchased.

div.head: TRAIN DERAILED.
div.p: As the 5.30 am. Luxor, Wednesday express train was leaving for Cairo this morning two of the carriages were derailed about half a mile from the station. The carriages were promptly replaced in their proper position and no serious accident happened, the train not having yet reached full speed.

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: LOOKING FOR THE ENEMY.

Suez, Thursday.- Last Tuesday night the Russian Baltic Fleet was sighted 80 miles south of Deadalus lighthouse, steaming very slow. During the whole night the battleships and cruisers were continually using their searchlights, apparently searching for the
enemy.
The battleship Sissoi Valiki was leading the way, while the destroyers were reconnoitring,

div.head: RAILWAY COMMISSION.
div.p: Luxor, Wednesday.-Lord Farrer's Commis- sion arrived here yesterday afternoon by special train in order to inspect the railway lines in Upper Egypt, and are proceeding to morrow afternoon by special train to Assouan. The commission is composed of Lord Farrer, Mr. Bury, Mr. Barois, administrator, and Capt. Blakeney, traffic manager.
We understand that the Railway Commission will submit their report on the Egyptian Rail- ways to Lord Cromer about the 12th inst., and leave Egypt about the 14th.

div.head: G. O. C. TO VISIT KHARTOUM.
div.p: The General Officer Commanding the Army of Occupation will arrive at Khartoum on the 7th inst. in the evening, and will be received at the station by a guard of honour composed of 2 officers, 50 men, and the band of the 2nd Rifle Brigade, with commanding officers and heads of departments, British Army of Occupation.
The inspection of the 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade will take place on the 8th, 9th, and 10th inst.
DEPARTURE OF 20TH HUSSARS.

The 20th Hussars arrived at Alexandria from Cairo by special troop train yesterday at 2.45 p.m. The troops disembarked on the quay where the transport Dunera was moored and immediately began to get their baggage on board the transport. The troops themselves embarked about 5 o'clock.
The embarkation of the troops was witnessed by Brig.-General Bullock, commanding the garrison, who was accompanied by Major Lattlow, D.A.A.G.
The Dunera sailed for Malta this morning at 7 o'clock.

div.head: WRECKED CREW AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Thursday.-The crew of the British steamer Pearlmoor, numbering 27, including the master, arrived at Suez on the 28th ult. After reporting themselves to the British Pro- Consul at Suez, they were sent on to Port Said for conveyance home.
The S.S. Pearlmoor was wrecked on the eKooria Moria Islands, in the Arabian Gulf. The vessel having been abandoned, the crew took to the boats and were picked up and brought to Suez.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
div.p: On the 12th inst., the Legislative Council will examine the Budget for 1905. The Govern- ment has informed the Council that it will consider the projected irrigation works be- tween Ghizeh and Assiout and the construction of a Barrage at Esneh as soon as the new Irrigation programme is completed.

div.head: IRRIGATION DEPARTMENT.
div.p: e Mr. Thomas B. Carter has been appointed surveyor of contracts of the 3rd class in the 1st Circle at a salary of L.E. 240 per annum, the Government reserving the right to transfer him, should the necessity arise, to the Sudan.

div.head: CAIRO AMUSEMENTS.
div.p: The Committee of Fêtes for Cairo met on Wednesday night. The following is their programme up to date:
Grand Ball with cotillon at Ghezireh Palace Hotel on January 2.
Battle of Flowers on January 29 or February 5.
Corso on March 7.
The question of fêtes at the Pyramids at night and of a Venetian fête on the Nile is being considered.

div.head: ITALIAN OPERA IN CAIRO.
div.p: The Italian opera company, under the direction of Sig. Ruotolo, gave their first. performance of Aida at the Verdi Theatre last night, the performance promised having been put off owing to the non-arrival of material... The company will give in all 40 performances, among which we notice the following operas now first given in Cairo: Siberia, by Giordano; Storie d'Amore, by Samara; La Bohème, by Leoncavallo; Cabrera, by Dupont; Manuel Menendez, by Fihasi; Chopin, by Orefice. Aida, Mignon, Carmen, Otello, and the usual favourite Italian operas will also be given by the com-
pany:

DELTA-HELOUAN RAILWAYS.
COMBINE SANCTIONED.
We are informed that the Delta Railway Company has received Government's approval to the fusion with the Cairo-Helouan Railway, and it is expected the line will be taken over at an early date.

div.head: DELTA LIGHT RAILWAYS, LTD.
div.p: This company has issued the report of the directors for the year ending 30th September, 1904, which will be presented to the shareholders at Winchester House, Old Broad-street, London. on 20th inst. We hope to reprint it in to-morrow's issue. We think it will be of great interest to our many readers who are also shareholders. The results are considered to be very satisfac- tory, the receipts having increased by £30,483, or 23%, whilst the expenses are only 10% more than last year.
The Board recommend the payment of a dividend of 5% for the year, which is 1% more than what was paid last year.
DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT CO., LTD.

This company has notified its shareholders that by resolution of the Board, and in pursu- ance of the terms of the prospectus, a call of 58. per share has been made and is payable on the 12th December, at the National Bank of Egypt, London, Cairo, or Alexandria.
Shareholders have also been informed that
1 the two further calls will be made on the 1st
f March and 2nd May, 1905. To meet the convenience of the proprietors, shares may be paid up in full on the 12th inst., and interest at the
1 rate of 2 per cent. per annum will be paid on all such prepayments from that date to dates when the calls fall due.
Warrants to bearer will be issued at an early date free of cost to all shareholders paying in full in advance.
LAND BANKS IN EGYPT.
It was only recently that the "Caisse Hypo-
thecaire" was founded here with the help of
Belgian capital, and now another land bank has
just been started in Egypt under the name of
Be the "Société Hypothecaire Belge." Egypt has
also the Land & Mortgage Co., the Credit
Foncier, and the Agricultural Bank. With
these two new accessions to this class of local
banking business, it is expected that the rate
of interest will be lowered considerably,
especially in view of the competition of the insurance companies.

div.head: IMPORTANT EXPLORATION EXPEDITION.
div.p: Prof. Flinders Petrie, accompanied by Mr. Monktorth, of Magdalene College, Oxford, is starting to-day for Sinai, for the purpose or If exploring and examining the ancient camping grounds and the malachite minés, the location of which is known but is not assigned on any map. The exploring party will proceed on camel and will consist of two Europeans and three natives, besides the above-mentioned gentlemen, who will make their headquarters at Sinai and will be absent until March.
Mr. Monktorth intends to make a special investigation into the flint instruments which the ancients used at the old camping grounds and elsewhere in Sinai.
The malachite is, we understand, found in mines embedded in sandstone.
UNHAPPY CAIRO MARRIAGE.

Edward Richard Mays, an engine-driver in the employment of the Egyptian Government, appeared before Sir Francis Jeune on Saturday week to be cross-examined on his petition for divorce from Margaret Mays, to whom he was married on July 7, 1899.

Mr. R. E. Moore stated that the petitioner, who was formerly in the Royal Engineers, had served as Lord Kitchener's engine-driver for three months during the Sudan campaign. In 1899 he was married to Margaret Appleby at the British Consular Office at Cairo. Disputes
arose between them from time to time until finally in August 1903 he took his wife to England, as he found her impossible to live with.

He had discovered that although he had allowed her £12 a month she had borrowed He money from several people at Cairo. brought her to reside in London with their two children near his parents, and on October e20, 1903, he returned to Egypt.
In September 1904 he heard by letter that S

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Menes arrived here yesterday afternoon from Liverpool, via Gibraltar and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Ellerman S.S. Fabian sailed this morning for Liverpool direct with general cargo, including 2,648 bales cotton.
The S.S. Egyptian, of the Westcott Line, left Malta this morning and is due here on Monday morning with general cargo from Antwerp and London.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal, which left Alexandria last Saturday, arrived at Marseilles yesterday at 8 a.m.
The Khedivial Mail S.S. Prince Abbas will leave Alexandria on Wednesday for Piraeus, Smyrna, Mitylene, and Constantinople.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes:-In spite of the official contradiction of the rumour that Chitty Bey is to be shortly appointed as Under-Secretary of State at the Ministry of Finance, it is generally believed that the Director General of the Customs Administration will be leaving Alexandria for Cairo in the course of next year to assume a high position in that Ministry. It is believed that the Customs Administration will be then run from Cairo as part and parcel of the Indirect Taxes Department of the Finance Ministry. In that case an official will be appointed to be the actual, but not the virtual, head of the Customs Administration at Alexandria.
The post of Sub-Director of the Administration will, it is believed, be abolished on the retirement of Michalla Pasha.
Among the arrivals at the Grand Continental Hotel we notice the Viscount de Farsa and family, from Paris, the Baron and Baroness de Neuten, and Furst Khevenhuller.
Baron M. Oppenheim is expected to return from leave on the 12th inst,

Among the latest arrivals at the Hotel d'Angleterre, Cairo, we notice Mrs. Fanny Barker, Miss Linley and Miss M. Carter, from London; the Rev. D. G. and and Mrs. Wise, Mrs. David Wright, the Misses Eddis, Mr. F. F. Churchill, M. and Mme Wolters, Miss Foster, Miss Thorne, Mlle. F. Weber, Mr. A. P. Stephens, Mr. H. T. Butcher, Mlle. Jenny Lissner, Dr. Franz Mayr.

The marriage of Miss Conegliano, the daughter of the popular manager of the Alhambra Theatre at Alexandria, to Mr. Benedetto Osmo took place yesterday. The religious ceremony was held at the Elias Hanabi Synagogue at 4.30 p.m. and a grand fête was given subsequently at the Alhambra, which had been beautifully decorated for the occasion. The buffet was excellent and the fête continued until a late hour this morning.

div.head: ESTATE OF ANTONIO COPPOLA, DECEASED.
div.p: ERRATUM.
Through inadvertence, the name of Giuseppe Coppola was given as Exeontor of the Will of ANTONIO COPPOLA, deceased: in the notice published in the Gasette on December 1, 1904.
The sole Executor named in the said Will, and to whom the notice in question refers, is Mr GIUSEPPE CHERUBINI.
For the Executor, GIUSEPPE, CHERUBINI. MARIO VELLA, Adronte

QUESTIONS MUNICIPALE: Différence provenant de
PROJET DE BUDGET DE 1905 RAPPORT DE L'ADMINISTRATEUR
(suite).
Droits du Tanzim

Nous prévoyons L.E. 1,800 en plus de l'année 1904, en nous basant sur les réalisations du 1er novembre 1903 à fin Octobre 1904 qui se sont élevées à L.E. 6.700. Cette augmentation est due à la surveillance plus stricte exercée sur les personnes qui occupent la voie publique et ur la vente croissante des Ziadehs de Tanzim, nécessitée par le redressement des rues.
Recettes diverses

La moyenne annuelle des encaissements effectués, de ce chef en 1901, 1902 et 1908, qui ont atteint L.E. 4.700, et 18 réalisations du 1er Novembre 1903 à fin Octobre 1904, qui se sont élevées à L.E. 5.026, nous permettons amplement de prévoir L.E. 4.100 pour 1905.
Retenue sur le traitement du personnel classé
pour le fonds de prévoyance.
En prévision du classement de 137 agents hors cadre, nous avons majoré le chef de L.E 200.
Moitié du produit de la vente des biens libres et location des immeubles libres de l'Etat.

Les déficits constatés sur les réalisations des exercices 1908 et 1904 nous obligent à réduire respectivement de L.E., 1,000 et L.E. 500 des prévisions de L.E. 5.000 et L.E. 3.500 inscrites aux Budgets des derniers exercices, sur l'indication du Gou- vernement, et qui faisaient partie des compensations accordées à la Municipalité lors de la suppression des droits d'octroi.
Autres chefs de recettes
La participation payée par les propriétaires pour l'asphaltage des trottoirs ainsi que les autres chefs de recettes sont maintenus aux chiffres prévus dans le budget de l'exercice en cours.

"Pourtant il serait utile de faire remarquer combien est minime la somme de L.E. 2.000 que le Gouvernement nous alloue annuellement pour les Services Sanitaires par rapport aux dépenses supportées par la Municipalité et qui s'élèvent, pour 1905, à L.E. 8.470, tandis qu'en 1893 première année du transfert desdits services A la Municipalité, les dépenses n'étaient que de L.E 1.840.
Personnel
Le Budget est établi d'après les moyennes portées sur le tableau A ci-après et qui ont été approuvées par la Commission municipale dans sa séance du 7 Novembre 1904.
la moyenne des 13 nouveaux postes
Total
Il y a lieu de noter que la moyenne des classes ne sera atteinte que graduellement

En consultant le tableau C, on remarque que la différence entre les traitements à payer effectivement en 1905 et ceux ins de L.E. Crite au Budget de 1904 n'est que 1.968, nécessaires pour porter chaque employé au minimum de sa nouvelle classe.

Je crois en outre qu'une somme de L.E. 600 environ, serait amplement suffisante pour augmenter, dans la première année, les traitements des divers autres employés méritants, tout en laissant une marge de L.E. 2.500 sur la moyenne générale des
classes.
Ainsi, pour 1905 l'augmentation de mandée pour la personnel classé ne s'élève effectivement qu'à L E. 2.600 environ.

Mais, par contre, il faut noter que par la fusion des Services de la Perception et de la Propriété Bâtie, la mise à la retraite du chef de ce dernier service et par la suppression d'un poste de délégué au Service de la perception, nous économisons L.E. 696. En ajoutant L.E. 800 provenant de la différence sur les traitements de l'Admi- nistrateur, nous obtenons une économie de L.E. 996.

Le Secrétaire Financier étant transféré au poste du Directeur du Service des Recettes, nous le proposons pour une augmentation de L.E. 72 par an, amplement justifiée par ses longues années de service et par le travail accompli depuis le 1er Août dernier au Service de la Perception, travail qui a eu pour résultat un surcroît notable des recettes et la perception de sommes considérées comme irrécouvrables.
Vous observerez donc que l'augmentation n'est pas grande et qu'en acceptant le classement vous aurez un personnel équitablement traité.
Je suis convaincu d'ailleurs qu'en stimulant le zèle de son personnel, l'Administration recouvre facilement la somme qu'elle affecte pour lui.
Autres dépenses.

Nous basant sur les majorations de crédits budgétaires faites en 1904 pour faire face aux dépenses strictement nécessaires de l'Administration, nous avons majoré pour 1905 divers crédits du budget en cours afin d'éviter autant que possible les demandes de crédits supplémentaires dans le courant de l'année.
Administration Centrale. L'ensemble des dépenses diverses & ete majoré de L.E. 300.
Service des Recettes.

Nous laissons à l'appréciation de la Com- mission Municipale l'inscription au Budget de 1905 d'une somme de L.E. 400 néces- Dans leur établissement nous nous som-saire pour accorder aux percepteurs une mes inspirés des deux considérations sui- gratification à raison de 3 millièmes par
vantes :
1o Les classes doivent présenter une certaine élasticité, leur moyenne totale ne devant pas être dépassée.
2° Pour avoir de bons employés il faut les rétribuer convenablement et suivant l'importance de leurs fonctions.
Ces conditions sont essentielles et elles sont la base même d'une bonne administration et d'un classement rationnel et durable.

Par ce classement nous améliorons particulièrement la situation du personnel inférieur qui mérite toute la sollicitude de la Commission municipale. Ainsi 66 employés touchent de L.E. 2 1/2 à 3 1/3 par mois, passent à la classe 4-7.
mesure quittance, cette n'ayant été prise par la Commission, dans sa séance du 18 Juin dernier, qu'à titre provisoire
pour 1904.
Service du Nettoiement.
Nous avons augmenté de L.E. 1.055, les crédits affectés aux journaliers de l'arrosage et du balayage, pour renforcer le nombre des ouvriers et les maintenir jusqu'à la fin de l'exercice.

Nous conformant aussi à la décision de la Délégation en date du 8 Novembre courant, nous avons fait figurer, dans les proportions budgétaires de l'exercice 1905, un crédit de L.E. 150 pour assurer, au moyen
des charrettes, le prompt enlèvement des
immondices placées dans les rues et pro- venant de maisons infectées de maladies contagieuses.
Parcs et Plantations

Le Gouvernement lui-même prend actuellement des mesures pour l'amélioration de la situation de son personnel en général et je viens d'apprendre qu'une commission spéciale étudiera probablement les moyens Afin d'augmenter le nombre des ouvriers d'améliorer, d'une façon sensible, la situa-jardiniers dont nous avons besoin pour le tion de son personnel inférieur, dont les bon entretien des parcs et plantations de traitements actuels sont du reste supérieurs la ville, nous avons majoré de L.E. 257 le ceux du cotre. crédit affecté au dit Service en le portant à L E. 2.450.

Je crois inutile de vous faire remarquer combien il serait imprudent de livrer notre personnel à la tentation de quitter notre Administration pour chercher des postes plus lucratifs dans les emplois du Gouvernement ou ailleurs, comme cela est du reste arrivé pour une partie de nos meilleurs employés.

D'autre part, il y a lieu de prendre en sérieuse considération que, depuis quelques années, les besoins de la vie matérielle ont considérablement surenchéri, sans que les émoluments du personnel soient augmentés en proportion.
La moyenne totale des traitements du personnel classé est de L.E. 83.294.

Elle comprend les traitements de 290 employés dont 137 agents hors cadre qui sont proposés pour le classement ainsi que ceux de 18 nouveaux postes dont la création s'impose pour la réalisation et la bonne marche des divers services." La différence entre les crédits inscrits au Budget de l'exercice 1904 et la moyenne des classes est de L.E. 5.112, comme il appert du tableau B.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that the ANNUAL ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING of the Company will be held in Hall No. 43, Winchester House, Old Broad Street, in the City of London, on TUESDAY, 20th DECEMBER, 1904, at 12 o'clock noon precisely," for the purpose of receiving the Directors" Report and Balance Sheet for the period ended 30th September, 1904, electing Directors, in the place of the three retiring by rotation, appointing Auditors for the ensuing year and fixing their remuneration, declaring a Dividend, and transacting the Ordinary General Business of the Company, and also for the purpose of considering and, if thought fit, passing the following Resolution then intended to be proposed that is to say:

THAT the Capital of the Company be increased by the creation of 39,460 new Preference shares of the nominal amount of 210 each, and that such Preference shares be issued and allotted by the Board upon such terms and conditions as they may determine, but such shares shall be issued upon the terms (subject to the powers of the Board ander Article 165 to set aside Sinking Funds and otherwise) that the sarpins profits in each year after providing for a dividend on the amounts from time to time paid or credited as paid otherwise than in advance on all Preference shares at the rate of 5 per cent. for such year shall be applied first in making up the arrears of dividend on the Preference Shares of the Company previously issued in respect of the period previous to the date of issue of the new Preference Shares hereby authorised, and when those arrears have been paid then in paying up the arrears (if any) which may subse- quently accrue on all Preference Shares in the order in which such arrears may be socrued and thereafter the sum of 10s. 9d. per cent. per annum on the said £34,600 of new Capital as part of the sinking Fund heretofore authorised in respect of the previous Capital so as to insure the repayment of the whole of the Share Capital authorised up to the date hereof in its due order of priority under the Articles, Baye as aforesaid the said new Preference Shares of the Company. Dated this 80th day of November, 1904.
211, GRESHAM HOUSE,
By order of the Board,"
F. J. HORNE,
OLD BROAD STREET, LONDON, E.C.
Secretary.

N.B Shareholders who hold Share Warrants to Bearer and whose names are not on the share Registers of the Company are reminded that if they wish to attend this General Meeting of the Company, they must first deposit their Bearer Warrants together with a statement in writing of their names and addresses as she Registered Offices of the Company in London two clear days before, the date of the General Meeting, viz. :-not later than the 17th December, 1904, or wish the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo or Alexandria, ten clear days before the date of the General Meeting, viz. no later than the 9th December, 1904. The Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held. div.head: ELEMENTARY EDUCATION
div.p: IN EGYPT.
II.
KUTTABS AND GRANTS-IN-AID.
(Concluded.)
The question as to what significance is to be attached to inspection returns is answered thus:-

"No absolute meaning or value can be attached to each of the standards of efficiency recorded. The best of the school premises can the considered satisfactory, the most meritor- ious of the fikis efficient, and the most suc- cessful of the kuttabs well managed, only in comparison with the conditions that prevail in the kuttabs generally. Even in awarding grants- in-aid it has not yet been found possible to insist on any rigid standard of efficiency, and the sums awarded, especially as regards the grant of the 2nd class, must at present be regarded as an encouragement of efforts put forth. forth rather than as a recognition of any definite level of efficiency reached. The figures ld be looked at as indicating tendencies rather than definité results. But even without attaching to the figures more significant than they really bear, the numbers under every Threading show gratifying progress."

The writer of the report proceeds to show that the crux of the difficulty in reforming the uttabs is in the creation of a supply of quafied teachers. At present no such source exists. The plan of the Ministry is gradually to train the pupil teachers (arifs):

- "The adoption of this expedient would have the advantage that it would not involve any rapid or general displacement of the present race of fikis, who would still remain attached to the schools and devote themselves to the religious teaching. There are strong reasons why such supersession as regards the mass of the kattabs of the country should be avoided as far and as long as possible. Ignorant and illiterate though they be, these men are people of 'some influence in their own quarters and villages, their life-work is closely interwoven with the religious tenets and traditions of the people, and it would be highly impolitic to excite their apprehension, and provoke their hostility by measures which seem to threaten too clearly or too, closely their extinction."

If this plan can be carried through "the Egyptian educational system would then be fairly complete. In each village would be the very elementary kuttab, at each markaz an gefficient vernacular school, in the chief town of each province the European primary school, in the chief cities the Industrial School and the European Secondary School, and in the Capital, the Professional and Technical Col- leges. The kuttabs of each markaz would be linked as auxiliary institutions to the markaz school, and the markaz schools would open out upwards for those desirous of continuing a school, career into the one year's normal course for teachers in kuttabs, the workshop-courses in the Technical and Industrial Schools, and the extra-mural course in the Agricultural School-thus providing a practical education and opening out careers of usefulness for the many who lack the means or the wish to follow a European course of study. For the wealthier classes the system would offer the European course, leading from the markaz school through the Provincial Primary School to the City Secondary School and the Professional and Technical Colleges in the Capital. -The missing link at present is the markaz school."

The last pages of the report are filled with carefully compiled statistics and appendices. here is, however, one passage of general interest with which our extracts must conclude:- "The great evil at present in the kuttabs is the stagnation in the lowest stages of the course. Thus of the 76,228 pupils in attendance in kuttabs, over 1000 do not yet know their letters, over 34,000 have not yet commenced to write, and over 43,000 have not yet, in arith- metic, reached the first standard, which consists of notation and numeration as far as hundreds and addition and subtraction mentally of numbers not greater than 12: As regards writing from the Arabic standpoint, i.e., caligraphy, the inspectors report that 51,000 of the pupils have no notion of the proper way to form and combine the letters. Restricted as the prescribed course is, only about 6% of the pupils at present reach its higher stages. It is obvious that the system of individual teaching prevalent in kuttabs is in part responsible for this appalling stagnation. The pushing and presumptuous secure attention, the bulk of the pupils never receive any instruction at all. The attention of the inspectors has been drawn to this evil, and every effort is being directed

to remedying it. It is satisfactory to find that in 1,033 of the kuttabs an attempt is now made to teach in classes. It is only by the cultivation of good class-teaching, and the improvement of the discipline in the kuttabs, that this terrible wastage of school life can be averted."

div.head: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION.
div.p: On the occasion of Beyram, His Highness the Khedive will hold a reception on the 1st Chawal 1321 (probably Friday next) at Abdeen Palace, when visitors will observe the following hours and order:

At 8.15 a.m.-The Ulema the General Assembly and the Legislative Council; the Governors of Cairo, Alexandria, the Suez Canal, Damietta and Suez, the Moudirs, Moudirieh officials, and Notables of the Provinces; the pupils of the Government Schools.

At 9.45 a.m.-Their Highnesses the Princes of the Khedivial Family; the President of the Council of Ministers and the Ministers; the Financial Adviser; the Judicial Adviser; the Adviser at the Ministry of the Interior; the Under Secretaries of State; Naval and Military officers of the rank of Bimbashi and upwards.

At 10.15 a.m.-The former Presidents of the Council of Ministers, Ministers, Presidents of the Legislative Council, Sirdars, Grand Masters of Ceremonies, Chiefs of the Khedivial Cabinet, Chief Aides-de-Camp, Directors of the Khedi- vial Khassa, Directors General of Wakfs, Under Secretaries of State, unofficial civil and military personages having the rank of Lewa or Oulaf Sinf Sani and upwards, officers of the Navy and Army on pension or on the retired list, of the rank of Kaimakam or Miralai; civil Beys not in office, of the rank of Moutemaiz and Sanieh.
At 10.45 a.m.-The Diplomatic and Consular Corps.

At 11 a.m.-The Public Debt Commissioners; the Director General and Controllers of the Daïra Sanieh; the Administrators of State Domains; the Administrators of the Railways, Telegraphs and the Port of Alexandria.
At 11.30 a.m.-The field officers of the Army of Occupation; the Clergy; the Mixed Magistracy; the Native Magistracy.

Decorations will be worn. Naval and Military officers will be in full dress uniform; natives and foreigners of rank or exercising duties obliging them to wear a special uniform, will wear those uniforms. Native and Euro- pean officials whose rank or duties do not oblige them to wear a uniform will appear in stambouline, with black trousers. Non-official Europeans and those without rank will wear dress suits. Natives who wear national costume will be receive in that costume.

The civil officials to be admitted to this reception are those holding, at least, the rank of sub-director or an equivalent rank, and those holding, at least, the rank of Sanieh or Kaima- kam and magistrates appointed by decree.
Names may be registered for H.H. the Khedivah at the Bureau of Ceremonies of the Harem, beside the Gate of Honour of Abdeen Palace.
H.H. the Khedivah will also hold a reception on the 1st Chawal, when her Highness will receive as follows:-
From 9 to 11.30 a.m. The Princesses of the Khedivial Family and native ladies. Prom 3.30 to 4.15 p.m.-European ladies. At 4.20 p.m.- The ladies of the Corps Diplomatique.

ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK.
ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING.

Mr. Thomas Usborne, who presided on Tues- day week at the meeting of the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, said that of the issue of 20,000 new shares the shareholders took up the quota to which they were entitled to the extent of 18,000; the remaining 2,000 were sold on the Stock Exchange at £12 each, net to the bank, or £2 premium on the issue price, giving the bank a profit of £4,000. From this had to be deducted £1,000, the cost of issue, mostly Government stamps, leaving a net profit of £3,000. This £3,000 they proposed to use in paying the staff a bonus of 10 per cent. on their salaries for the past year. They had been well served by the staff for the last 16 years during which he had occupied the chair, and their ability and industry had enabled him to call every one of those years a "record" one. This was the first bonus that they had proposed to give the staff, and he hoped they would not have to wait so long for the next one. The reserve fund amounted to £500,000, equal to the paid-up capital, and he felt sure that not one shilling of that reserve could ever be required to make good any account now standing on the books, so that the most nervous shareholder or depositor ought to feel quite comfortable.
NEXT YEAR'S PROFIT APPROPRIATION.

It had been his practice for many years to prophesy as to the profits which they hoped to show next year. But on that occasion he was not going to do so. He meant instead to tell them what the policy of the board would be in dealing with the profit, whatever it might prove to be. The first charge on the profit would be £62,500, or 12 per cent. dividend on the capital; the second charge, subscription to staff provident fund £1,500; the third charge, the very large amount of £30,000 to establish a pension fund for the benefit of the staff. After these charges the balance would go to increase the carry-forward. They had had 16 consecutive "record" years, and if at the next meeting he was able to announce another, then, as the new capital with the premium at which it had been issued must be worth £8,000 to them, there would be something substantial to add to the carry-forward.
UNPRECEDENTED PROVISION
FOR THE STAFF.

The £30,000 for the pension fund was undoubtedly a very large sum, equal, as it was, to 6 per cent. on the capital of the bank. It would become the property of the staff, and the scheme for its appropriation to individuals would be carefully drawn up by the solicitors before the meeting next year. A clause would be inserted in that scheme giving the board alone the power to decide on the right of any individual to make a claim on the fund, and they hoped to have it so drawn up that under no circumstances would it be possible for any retired member of the staff to bring an action against the bank. They wished, however, the staff to know that this fund belonged to them, and that at no time could any portion of it be diverted from them. They considered it in the shareholders' interest to grant it, as it would prevent the necessity of adding to it should times in the future not be so prosperous as they have been in the past. They proposed to credit the fund every year with interest at the rate which they would at the time be paying on fixed annual deposits, and they hoped at times to be able to credit it with moderate contributions from profits. Some shareholders might naturally ask "Why make this statement to-day? Why not wait until this time next year ?" His reply was that in this matter he was not only speaking to the shareholders but to the staff of the bank, and if he could make those gentlemen comfortable about their future, and consequently more likely to stick to their posts, he could not do so too soon; and another reason for his doing so. was that he did not wish to spring on them this proposal, which for its magnitude compared to the capital of the bank, was, he believed, without precedent.
PROTEST AS TO EXPENSES.

Mr. W. H. Skeel congratulated the directors on the position of the bank, and expressed the hope that it would long occupy the state it had now reached. He expressed the desire that half-yearly meetings should be held.
Mr. W. Watson endorsed the remarks of the last speaker, and referred to the increase in the expenses, which he hoped were not likely to advance further...

The Chairman said that he much appreciated the complimentary remarks of the shareholders. As to half-yearly meetings they would entail extra work and outlay and the interim dividend was an estimated one. As to expenditure he feared there must be an annual advance, the officers naturally looking for increased remuneration as they stayed longer with the bank. Two new branches had been opened which in some degree added to the expenses. The new shares would be "good delivery" at the mid- December account; he had personally ascertained that on the Stock Exchange.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit within certain necessary limits-free discussion,
GERMAN POLICY.

To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE, Sir,-In regard to Count von Bülow's statements in your telegram of yesterday, as to the pacific character of Germany's policy towards England, it is worth while recalling that when 1 the Imperial Chancellor was asked in the Reichstag in the most pointed terms whether git was true that the Kaiser had really made e the famous signal to the Tsar, "The Admiral of the Atlantic greets the Admiral of the "Pacific," Count von Bülow made no re- ference to it in his reply, for the excellent reason that he could not deny it, and it was not convenient to avow it. Everybody knows now that this grandiloquent boast was made from the Royal yacht at the close of the Reval 8 meeting between the two Emperors. I should 1 be glad to treat the offensive phrase as a mere 1 symptom of "tête montée'' rather than a challenge to the only Power which could with tany plausibility lay claim to such a title. But the Kaiser's indiscretions, as in the case of the Kruger telegram, are never without an object, and we are bound to associate these words, and the occasion on which they are uttered, with the well-known ambitions of their august author. The Germans have practically no coast to guard: a glance at any chart will show the intricate network of sandbanks and channels which render the mouth of the Elbe unapproach- able. They have no columns that are worth protecting, their only trade routes are depen- dent on highly subsidised vessels, and in the majority of cases for British ports. Take one by one the ordinary excuses for naval extension, and apply them to Germany, and they break down utterly. For what reason and against whom, but England, is German naval policy directed? Count von Bülow's statements will deceive nobody.
I am, Sir,

The Editor of the Egyptian Gavelle will be pleased to receive communications dealing with matters of local interest, for publication. Notes of events occurring in the Provinces are especially welcome. All communications should be sent to Ta. EDITOR," and be accompanied by the Writer's Name and Address, not necessarily for insertion, but as a guarantee of good faith.
